summary: Email correspondence from May 2021 between a retired Palm Beach Police Department Crime Scene/Evidence Unit Manager and a federal prosecutor's office regarding an upcoming videocall interview as a prosecution witness in the SDNY case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The retired manager discusses obtaining property receipts and notes the difference in deposition rules between Florida and New York federal court.

persons.name: Retired Crime Scene/Evidence Unit Manager
persons.role: Retired Police Evidence Manager / Prosecution Witness
persons.context: Retired manager from Palm Beach Police Department communicating with federal prosecutors about an upcoming videocall interview regarding the Epstein/Maxwell case, offering to obtain property receipts from PBPD.

events.title: SDNY Videocall Interview Scheduled
events.description: Scheduled videocall interview between the retired PBPD evidence manager and federal prosecutors regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

events.title: Planned Retrieval of Property Receipts
events.description: The retired manager plans to obtain copies of property receipts from the Palm Beach Police Department headquarters.

keyFacts: A retired Palm Beach Police Department evidence manager is scheduled to be interviewed as a prosecution witness in the SDNY case against Ghislaine Maxwell.
The witness states they do not have any photos or documents at home and will answer questions from memory.
The witness notes a procedural difference: New York federal court does not subject prosecution witnesses to depositions, unlike Florida state practice.
The correspondence is subject to a protective order covering specific paragraphs (7, 8, 9, 10, 15, and 17).
